title: 113_s2586
content: The "Medicare Common Access Card Act of 2014" establishes a Secure Medicare Card Pilot Program. The Secretary will conduct a pilot program under the Social Security Act to utilize smart card technology for Medicare beneficiary and provider identification cards. The program aims to improve care quality, billing accuracy, reduce identity theft, and combat waste, fraud, and abuse in the Medicare program. The Secretary will conduct a pilot program in high-risk areas to utilize smart card technology for Medicare beneficiary and provider identification cards, aiming to reduce waste, fraud, and abuse in the Medicare program. The program includes issuing new smart cards with security features and protecting personal privacy. The pilot program for Medicare beneficiary and provider identification cards will involve issuing new smart cards with security features. The cards will not display Social Security numbers or Medicare provider numbers on the front but will store them securely on the smart card chip along with other necessary information. The enrollment process for Medicare providers will include identity and certification verification. The pilot program for Medicare beneficiary and provider identification cards includes issuing smart cards with security features. These cards will utilize biometric data like fingerprints for authentication. They will be used by both beneficiaries and providers to verify eligibility, prevent fraud, and authorize transactions. Necessary equipment will be distributed at no cost, and regular monitoring will be conducted to identify billing discrepancies. The pilot program aims to use smart cards with biometric data for Medicare beneficiaries and providers to prevent fraud and verify eligibility. It includes measures to identify inaccurate charges and ensure compliance with security standards. The pilot program aims to use smart cards with biometric data for Medicare beneficiaries and providers to prevent fraud and verify eligibility. It includes measures to protect personal information, use two-factor authentication, develop procedures for identity verification, and ensure compliance with security standards. The Medicare pilot program informs beneficiaries and providers about the program's purpose, enrollment processes, use of biometric data, and measures to protect personal information. The Medicare pilot program includes measures for unauthorized access and disclosure, addressing equipment problems, developing a hotline for assistance, and addressing issues with accessing care outside the pilot area. Information on the smart card is limited to privacy concerns. The smart card information can only be disclosed in accordance with Federal privacy regulations. Information on the smart card is exempt from disclosure under specific code. The Secretary has the authority to expand the pilot program's duration and scope through rulemaking. The Secretary also has the power to waive certain provisions of the Social Security Act. The Secretary will submit reports to Congress regarding the design, development, and evaluation of the pilot program, including the deployment of the program, usability of the card system, and measures to protect beneficiary and provider information. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program within 2 years of implementation, detailing issues related to program expansion and providing recommendations for nationwide implementation. $29,000,000 is appropriated for the pilot program's design, implementation, and evaluation. In this section, definitions for key terms related to the Medicare program are provided, including Medicare beneficiary, Medicare program, Medicare provider, and pilot program. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to a pilot program, including the term "Secretary" and "smart card" as a secure electronic card with an embedded chip. The Social Security Act is amended to revise funding for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation, allocating $8.9 billion for activities from 2020 to 2030.
